results.title: Day the world ended
results.creator_credit: Roger Corman and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: B-grade science-fiction from Roger Corman, set in a post-nuclear holocaust world. Just a few survivors are holed up at a ranch (protected from the nuclear fallout by a mountain range) where nerves are frayed and romantic rivalry erupts. These issues are swept aside however when a radioactive mutant creature terrorises the group. Accomplished low budget thriller (reputedly shoot in 9 days) was one of the first to present the horrors of a post-nuclear wasteland — a lawless place, lurking with unpredictable threats. Cast includes: Richard Denning, Lori Nelson, and Jonathan Haze.

results.title: Day One [videogame trailer]
results.brief_description: Winner in the Middle Videogame. In 2017, tens of thousands of Australians will battle the greatest mystery of their lives … high school. In ‘Day One’, your mission is to survive your first day of high school. You will need to find your seat in assembly, learn a new instrument, escape detention, sprint 100 metres, destroy a vending machine, and dodge rubbish bins to ultimately find your classroom.

results.title: Day of wrath
results.creator_credit: Carl Theodor Dreyer and Palladium Films
results.brief_description: Set in 17th century Europe, “Day of Wrath” is an intense and tragic study of how a young woman is destroyed by the charge of witchcraft. Anne is married to the much older pastor, Absalon Pedersson. She is attracted to her step-son Martin and when Absalon dies of a heart attack, the accusations begin that his death was caused through Anne’s sorcery. Now considered one of the great works of European cinema, “Day of Wrath” is not interested in the occult as much as it explores the psychology of harsh puritanism, especially the debilitating effects of such repression on women. From her initial horror at the accusations, to her remorse and final acceptance, Anne’s story transcends the supernatural and becomes a terrifyingly contemporary study of alienation and emotional betrayal. Based on the play “Anne Pedersdotter” by Wiers Jenssens, Dreyer has reconceived the story and created one of the great feminist works of cinema. Released in Denmark during the Nazi occupation, “Day of Wrath” resonates as a study of terror, hatred and collaboration. With Thorkid Roose, Ilsbeth Movin and Sigrid Neiiendam. In Danish with English subtitles.

results.title: Day of the evil gun
results.brief_description: When Forbes’ (Arthur Kennedy) family is kidnapped by Apache Indians he enlists the help of his gun-slinging neighbour Warfield (Glenn Ford) and a scout called Jimmy Noble (Dean jagger) in a rescue bid to get his family back. What follows is a sequence of events that will change the personalities of each of the men leading to an eventual showdown. Cast also includes John Anderson, Harry Dean Stanton, Paul Fix, Nico Minardos.

results.title: Day of the dead (D)
results.creator_credit: George A. Romero, Richard Rubinstein, Laurel Productions and United Film Distribution Company
results.brief_description: The third and bleakest of George A. Romero’s ‘Living dead’ series (which consist of ‘Night of the living dead’ and ‘Dawn of the dead’), is also the most goriest. Essentially, society has collapsed and the living dead have taken over the world. The film picks up on a small group of survivors, made up of scientists and a small band of soldiers who have barricaded themselves in an abandoned missile silo. The scientists desperately search for a solution to the zombie plague, while the military become increasingly agitated at their lack of results. Like Romero’s previous outings into the world of the undead, the varied groups are microcosms of human nature and not surprisingly, the most unpleasant characters in this film are not the zombies but the humans themselves. Cast includes Lori Cardille, Terry Alexander, Joe Pilato, Richard Liberty and Howard Sherman.

results.title: Day for night = La Nuit Americaine [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Francois Truffaut, Marcel Berbert, Produzione International Cinematografica, Productions et Editions Cinematographic Francaise and Les Films du Carrosse
results.brief_description: Some critics saw Francois Truffaut’s loving homage to filmmaking as a lightweight addition to the canon of his more crucial work. Nevertheless, “Day for night” went on to win Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards (1974) and is an enduring comedy about the vagaries of the movie business. Ferrand (played by Francois Truffaut) is a director working on his latest project, a melodrama called ‘Meet Pamela’, with an international cast. His leading man (Truffaut stalwart Jean-Pierre Leaud) is an insecure egoist conducting an obsessive affair with a free-spirited script-girl, given to irascible behaviour. The leading actress, recovering from a nervous breakdown, is American, and insecure about her talents. Additionally an aging actress, drinking heavily, continuously fluffs her lines, delaying a beleaguered production. Truffaut amuses by deftly expanding upon this set-up, exploring the difficulties of the filmmaking, including co-ordinating stunts, trying to induce animals to perform on cue, inconveniently pregnant cast members and nervous producers. Of greatest interest however is the behind-the-scenes romantic shenanigans that occur between the cast and crew, many of whom, despite the continuous frustrations, relay their love for the business of making movies. A light-hearted, whimsical and a wonderfully executed work. Cast includes Valentina Cortese, Alexandra Stewart, Jean-Pierre Aumont and Jean Champion.

results.title: Day care & the pre-school experience
results.creator_credit: Darrel Schwandt, George A. Colburn, GPN and DLGHS
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Overviews child care in modern industrialised societies and compares it to child care in hunter-gatherer and agricultural societies, emphasising the effect of child care on children.

results.title: Day by day
results.creator_credit: Robin James, Griffith University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: We look at some of the daily activities of the Chinese inhabitants of Beijing, beginning with Tai Chi exercises in the morning. Highlights work work, school, peasant farmers in a collective near Beijing, lunchtime, Children’s palaces where children may indulge in extra-curricular activities in sport and the arts, and Sunday visits to the park and the Forbidden City. Professor Colin Mackerras explains the history of calligraphy, and the ways in which the Chinese spend their time. Two dramatised segments show a grandfather sitting in the park and a family quarrel.
